title: 111_s3936
content: The "States as Energy Leaders for the Future Act" or "SELF Act" defines terms like "eligible entity" and "Secretary" for the Clean Energy Grant Program. The Department of Energy established a program to provide grants to eligible entities for clean energy and carbon reduction measures, including renewable electricity standards, climate action plans, use of alternative vehicles, energy efficiency standards for public buildings, participation in greenhouse gas reduction programs, and financing for energy efficiency improvements. The Department of Energy offers grants to eligible entities for clean energy initiatives, including improvements for rural coops, tax incentives for clean energy components, financing for clean energy technologies, grid technology updates, and carbon efficiency standards. Eligible entities must meet requirements set by the Secretary and submit an application for consideration. The Department of Energy provides grants to eligible entities for clean energy initiatives through partnerships with private sector and nongovernmental organizations. Eligible entities must meet requirements set by the Secretary and submit an application for consideration. The Secretary determines grant recipients and amounts based on application information and established criteria. Grant funds can only be used for eligible purposes specified by the Secretary through regulations. Regulations are issued to establish criteria for grants, including eligible measures. The Secretary issues regulations to establish criteria for grants under this section, specifying eligible measures, application criteria, and a point system for reviewing applications. Considerations include regional disparities in energy production and clean energy potential. Grants awarded ensure an objective evaluation based on the criteria regulations. Authorization of $5 billion for fiscal year 2011 to carry out the Act, with funds remaining available until expended. Cost offset for clean energy grant program and deficit reduction by denying deduction for major integrated oil companies for income from domestic production of oil, gas, or primary products. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include provisions related to major integrated oil companies and oil-related qualified production activities. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010.
